section.title: Required KBML tags
section.p: These tags are required in a correctly formatted DITA topic document:

dlentry.dd: The <topic> tag is the top level element for DITA topic documents. The <topic> tag has a required id attribute. See

The <title> tag contains the title of a document and must appear as the first element. See You can create alternate titles for a document by adding them to the alt qlines document. For instructions on working with alternate a-lines, see Adding alternate q-lines.

The <body> tag contains the viewable contents of the DITA document. See The <body> element is only required insofar as it is a required container of any text nodes. The alt qline documents don't have any text other than the titles so they don't need <body> tags.

section.title: Special purpose DITA tags
section.p: These tags serve special purposes in DITA beyond semantic tagging of content.

dd.p: The <xref> element is DITA's general purpose tag for creating cross-referencing links. See . The DITA standard recommends using higher-level linking structures built into ditamaps over using <xref> elements to hardcode links at the topic level. For the KB, the <xref> element will take the place of the <kba> KBML element, as well as the regular HTML <a> element.

The <xref> element transcludes the text of the title of the link target similarly to the way the <kba> tag does. The <xref> element works differently in how to override the default title text: the <xref> element has no way of selecting an alternate qline as you can do with the qline attribute of the <xref> element. Instead, you can specify alternate text for the link by enclosing it within the <xref> element, as you would do with an HTML <a> element.
